title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body:
Religion is typically used as a vehicle for hate more than anything else these days.   As a moral guide, even most of the religious people don't use it unless they're using an outdated part, and they all universally selectively pick out the bits they like. Not once have I dealt with a religious person that doesn't eat shellfish and abstain from usury for religious reasons. For morals, there are better frameworks out there that aren't outdated or mandate conflict with other frameworks. 

All the magical stories really turned me off. It was a real shock that some people actually believe in them as literal truths. 

Epicurus's* reasoning on the fallacy/nature of an omnipotent god in a world with suffering really struck home.   *Funnily enough Epicurus didn't hold these views, but everyone attributes it to him.

The inconsistencies between different religions. I mean, which god are you talking about? And the fact that none of them have any better arguments for why their magic is or morals is more true than any other. If I was born elsewhere I would have been raised in a different religion. 

The inconsistencies in my parent's religion. We were catholic, apparently. But the very obvious tone-shift from the old testament to new testament meant... what? That god changes his mind?   And yet you think a book 2000 years old is the latest and greatest update?

The abuses of the church. 

Almost every aspect that used to be explained by "god did it" was explained by science. What remained was magic that obviously didn't happen or was a metaphor. And the religious types like creationists and friends really instituted a religion vs science mentality. Religion was for the closed-minded that didn't like to change their views. 

One of the few devoutly religious kids in my elementary was a real idiot. 

And I researched the origins of the bible and found that... it's poorly translated writings of the children of political activists or cult followers. Things like hell are mostly bad fanfiction made well after canon was established.   You know his name wasn't "Jesus", right?

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body_html:
most believe in Darwinian evolution

Kinda... it isn't a "belief" in the religious sense (at least in my case), it's more like "it's the best explanation we have for now, so I'm rolling with it".

Based on that theory, how do you mentally explain things like the beginning of life, and the cause of the big bang?

Darwin's theory was made to explain how species change and diversify, not the origin of life or the universe. That said:

origin of life

I think abiogenesis with RNA world are together the best hypotheses we have, as they don't add unnecessary complexity, and they fit well RNA's general behaviour. To keep it simple:

  • earlier aminoacids and nucleobases are generated by natural processes;
  • through the chemical interactions between those, an auto-catalysing molecule (RNA's "ancestor") appears;
  • as it's an auto-catalyst, that molecule speeds up its own production, until that stuff is everywhere;
  • small changes in the molecule's configuration and composition are bound to happen, due to its abundance;
  • some of those new configurations+compositions are even better auto-catalysts, so they eventually become more common than the original molecule;
  • eventually, the best auto-catalyst generated in the process is what we know as RNA.

[Note I'm being extremely simplistic. People write 200 pages theses on this stuff.]

origin of the universe

There are plenty hypotheses on what happened before the Big Bang; nobody knows for sure. In my opinion the oscillatory universe hypothesis looks promising. (In this hypothesis, the universe would go through cycles of expansion and eventual contraction. It wouldn't have a "start" or an "end".)

My trust in that hypothesis is lower than in RNA world though, and way lower than in Darwinian evolution.

body:
Regarding the oscillatory universe hypothesis, it couldn't be infinite, because how could infinite time have already progressed?

Also, you still have to question what formulated that structure - it's too complex to occur for no reason. And honestly it requires a lot more faith to believe that life comes from non-life, and the universe created itself, than to believe in an omnipotent God who created life and the universe.

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body:
>Regarding the oscillatory universe hypothesis, it couldn't be infinite, because how could infinite time have already progressed?

"Progress" would require a point of reference; a beginning. But under that hypothesis, there wouldn't be a beginning, we could at most say "in comparison with *now*, it *regresses* infinitely". 

>Also, you still have to question what formulated that structure - it's too complex to occur for no reason.

We don't need anyone "formulating" a chemical reaction, in order for it to happen. Given the right conditions it will eventually happen, for no other reason than "both molecules hit each other in a specific angle".

Lemme use an analogy. You're in the corner of a room, blindfolded, trying to throw a grain of rice inside a tiny glass in the opposite corner of the room. You'll likely fail, right? Right. But what if you tried again, with another grain of rice? And again? What if you had a billion grains of rice, and enough patience to keep trying? Then it's likely you'd be able to throw *at least* one grain inside that small glass.

In other words: yes, it is complex, but even complex events are bound to succeed if repeated enough times. Chemistry works *a lot* like this - on a molecular level even statistically unlikely reactions are happening all the time. 

And once that first self-replicating molecule pops up, from trivial reactions (no matter how unlikely they are!), it starts replicating like crazy, exponentially. And as there are more and more copies of that molecule, the odds some mutation makes it a better self-replicator *also* increase.

>And honestly it requires a lot more faith to believe that life comes from non-life, and the universe created itself, than to believe in an omnipotent God who created life and the universe.

But wouldn't a god - specially an omnipotent god, as the Jewish/Christian Yahweh - be *even more complex?*

It's also worth noting I don't really have "faith" on those two hypotheses. If they turn out wrong, for me, there's still no reason to believe in gods - again, doubt is my default.
body_html:
Regarding the oscillatory universe hypothesis, it couldn't be infinite, because how could infinite time have already progressed?

"Progress" would require a point of reference; a beginning. But under that hypothesis, there wouldn't be a beginning, we could at most say "in comparison with now, it regresses infinitely".

Also, you still have to question what formulated that structure - it's too complex to occur for no reason.

We don't need anyone "formulating" a chemical reaction, in order for it to happen. Given the right conditions it will eventually happen, for no other reason than "both molecules hit each other in a specific angle".

Lemme use an analogy. You're in the corner of a room, blindfolded, trying to throw a grain of rice inside a tiny glass in the opposite corner of the room. You'll likely fail, right? Right. But what if you tried again, with another grain of rice? And again? What if you had a billion grains of rice, and enough patience to keep trying? Then it's likely you'd be able to throw at least one grain inside that small glass.

In other words: yes, it is complex, but even complex events are bound to succeed if repeated enough times. Chemistry works a lot like this - on a molecular level even statistically unlikely reactions are happening all the time.

And once that first self-replicating molecule pops up, from trivial reactions (no matter how unlikely they are!), it starts replicating like crazy, exponentially. And as there are more and more copies of that molecule, the odds some mutation makes it a better self-replicator also increase.

And honestly it requires a lot more faith to believe that life comes from non-life, and the universe created itself, than to believe in an omnipotent God who created life and the universe.

But wouldn't a god - specially an omnipotent god, as the Jewish/Christian Yahweh - be even more complex?

It's also worth noting I don't really have "faith" on those two hypotheses. If they turn out wrong, for me, there's still no reason to believe in gods - again, doubt is my default.

body:
Actually, an omnipotent God is simple - he just exists, outside of the limits time and space.

But an infinite timespan for the universe having no beginning would be chronologically impossible by any scientifically quantifiable measure. No end is conceivable, but no beginning, means that now occurring is impossible because infinite time would have had to already elapse.

With Christianity, there is a definite start point (creation) and end point (the final day) of time. Time didn't exist before God created it. Time after judgment doesn't exist anymore (as we experience it).
body_html:
Actually, an omnipotent God is simple - he just exists, outside of the limits time and space.

But an infinite timespan for the universe having no beginning would be chronologically impossible by any scientifically quantifiable measure. No end is conceivable, but no beginning, means that now occurring is impossible because infinite time would have had to already elapse.

With Christianity, there is a definite start point (creation) and end point (the final day) of time. Time didn't exist before God created it. Time after judgment doesn't exist anymore (as we experience it).

parent.body:
>Regarding the oscillatory universe hypothesis, it couldn't be infinite, because how could infinite time have already progressed?

"Progress" would require a point of reference; a beginning. But under that hypothesis, there wouldn't be a beginning, we could at most say "in comparison with *now*, it *regresses* infinitely". 

>Also, you still have to question what formulated that structure - it's too complex to occur for no reason.

We don't need anyone "formulating" a chemical reaction, in order for it to happen. Given the right conditions it will eventually happen, for no other reason than "both molecules hit each other in a specific angle".

Lemme use an analogy. You're in the corner of a room, blindfolded, trying to throw a grain of rice inside a tiny glass in the opposite corner of the room. You'll likely fail, right? Right. But what if you tried again, with another grain of rice? And again? What if you had a billion grains of rice, and enough patience to keep trying? Then it's likely you'd be able to throw *at least* one grain inside that small glass.

In other words: yes, it is complex, but even complex events are bound to succeed if repeated enough times. Chemistry works *a lot* like this - on a molecular level even statistically unlikely reactions are happening all the time. 

And once that first self-replicating molecule pops up, from trivial reactions (no matter how unlikely they are!), it starts replicating like crazy, exponentially. And as there are more and more copies of that molecule, the odds some mutation makes it a better self-replicator *also* increase.

>And honestly it requires a lot more faith to believe that life comes from non-life, and the universe created itself, than to believe in an omnipotent God who created life and the universe.

But wouldn't a god - specially an omnipotent god, as the Jewish/Christian Yahweh - be *even more complex?*

It's also worth noting I don't really have "faith" on those two hypotheses. If they turn out wrong, for me, there's still no reason to believe in gods - again, doubt is my default.
parent.body_html:
Regarding the oscillatory universe hypothesis, it couldn't be infinite, because how could infinite time have already progressed?

"Progress" would require a point of reference; a beginning. But under that hypothesis, there wouldn't be a beginning, we could at most say "in comparison with now, it regresses infinitely".

Also, you still have to question what formulated that structure - it's too complex to occur for no reason.

We don't need anyone "formulating" a chemical reaction, in order for it to happen. Given the right conditions it will eventually happen, for no other reason than "both molecules hit each other in a specific angle".

Lemme use an analogy. You're in the corner of a room, blindfolded, trying to throw a grain of rice inside a tiny glass in the opposite corner of the room. You'll likely fail, right? Right. But what if you tried again, with another grain of rice? And again? What if you had a billion grains of rice, and enough patience to keep trying? Then it's likely you'd be able to throw at least one grain inside that small glass.

In other words: yes, it is complex, but even complex events are bound to succeed if repeated enough times. Chemistry works a lot like this - on a molecular level even statistically unlikely reactions are happening all the time.

And once that first self-replicating molecule pops up, from trivial reactions (no matter how unlikely they are!), it starts replicating like crazy, exponentially. And as there are more and more copies of that molecule, the odds some mutation makes it a better self-replicator also increase.

And honestly it requires a lot more faith to believe that life comes from non-life, and the universe created itself, than to believe in an omnipotent God who created life and the universe.

But wouldn't a god - specially an omnipotent god, as the Jewish/Christian Yahweh - be even more complex?

It's also worth noting I don't really have "faith" on those two hypotheses. If they turn out wrong, for me, there's still no reason to believe in gods - again, doubt is my default.

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body:
A hypothetical god isn't simple at all, specially not the Monotheistic one. 

*Any* complexity that plagues the hypothesis of a timeless universe *also* affects the idea of a timeless god. If the universe *must* have a beginning, so does God; when was he born, where is he from, what was he doing before creating the universe? If the universe cannot be the primary cause, why would a God? etc. 

The opposite isn't true, however - not all complexity in the hypothetical god applies to the universe. A god would be external to the universe and yet capable to mess with it, sentient and conscientious and yet not matter-based, interested on humanity and yet avoiding any direct detection... 

Once we try to use the concept of a god to explain anything, the hypothesis gets *way* more complex, and we need to pile up a bunch of ad hoc to address it rationally. And a lot of Christians are aware of this too, as "credo quia absurdum" (I believe because [it's] absurd) attests.

Note some scientific hypotheses do suggest time appeared alongside the Big Bang, so even the argument "time didn't exist before God created the universe" can be reworded to exclude a god, as "time didn't exist before the universe appeared".

IMHO the idea that time goes infinitely *forward* and *backward* isn't unreasonable; in this sense time would behave like the other three dimensions, no boundaries whatsoever.

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body:
>an infinite timespan for the universe having no beginning would be chronologically impossible

It just exists.    That's it.... right? That's the end of the argument for you. If that's a simple and valid argument for god, then why would it be any different for a dimension? 

>an omnipotent God is simple - he just exists, 

No end is conceivable, but no beginning? That's impossible, where did it come from?  Even in a simulated environment, the creator has a creator.  

But... simple?   If there's an omnipotent god:

Why doesn't he do anything?

Why doesn't he reveal himself?

Why does he allow bad things to happen?

Why didn't he foresee all the bad things that were going to happen?

Why did he choose for all these bad things to happen? Cancer. Bone cancer.  Bone cancer in children.  If someone had the ability to fix that, and chose not to, then that's a pretty good argument that the person is not a good person. Not the sort you want to emulate. And certainly not the sort of person you want to take order or advice from. 

Does he have the ability to limit his own abilities?    Afterwards, is he still omnipotent? 

Can he make a rock so heavy even he can't lift it? 

If he's omnipotent and can see everything in the universe, why would he care about a speck of dust of one random galaxy? 

If he hand-made this world, and hand-made humans, why are there so many flaws? Cancer, as mentioned. But old-age, grey hair, balding, wisdom teeth, the need for a constant supply of vitamin C. Other animals don't need that. Others also just deal with cancer better Whales don't get cancer. Their immune system is simply better at fighting it. (They have to be, otherwise they have so many cells that cancer would take over before they hit maturity). Why are people born predisposed to addiction? Why are people born with deformities? What part of god's plan is to mentally cripple children? 

The concept of omnipotent actor raises a lot of questions. And I've heard a lot of mental gymnastics in response, but hardly the same thing twice.  It's a simple system as long as you shutdown your brain when your hit the period and stop questioning things. Science is in the business of questioning everything and trying to provide answers, even philosophical questions. Like the chicken and the egg. (lizards laid eggs far before chickens existed). And the tree in the forest. (yes, vibrations exist without people. But if you completely isolate a system, it all exists as a quantum waveform).

If the universe must have a beginning, so does God; when was he born, where is he from, what was he doing before creating the universe? If the universe cannot be the primary cause, why would a God? etc.

The opposite isn't true, however - not all complexity in the hypothetical god applies to the universe. A god would be external to the universe and yet capable to mess with it, sentient and conscientious and yet not matter-based, interested on humanity and yet avoiding any direct detection...

Once we try to use the concept of a god to explain anything, the hypothesis gets way more complex, and we need to pile up a bunch of ad hoc to address it rationally. And a lot of Christians are aware of this too, as "credo quia absurdum" (I believe because [it's] absurd) attests.

Note some scientific hypotheses do suggest time appeared alongside the Big Bang, so even the argument "time didn't exist before God created the universe" can be reworded to exclude a god, as "time didn't exist before the universe appeared".

IMHO the idea that time goes infinitely forward and backward isn't unreasonable; in this sense time would behave like the other three dimensions, no boundaries whatsoever.

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body:
Can you define "subsist" for me? The word has multiple meanings; and in philosophy it's sometimes used as "to exist independently, as a continued existence". I think you're using it as such, but better ask than assume.

Anyway, let's roll with it: why can't all those attributes be assigned to the universe instead? Unlike God, the universe is directly attested. And even if you say he doesn't require a universe, there's still the fact that, under the hypothesis of a god existing, he'd decide "out of nowhere" to create a universe - what would cause this change?

body:
Omnipotent, with the abilities of a designer, eternal? This is anything but simple.

The reason people usually use this "intelligent design" argument isn't to lower the perceived complexity of their gods, but rather to claim something is only explainable *if you introduce that complexity into the explanation*. If you want we can discuss on those grounds of intelligent design too, but IMHO it's a weak argument.

Omnipotent, with the abilities of a designer, eternal? This is anything but simple.

If you want we can discuss on those grounds of intelligent design too, but IMHO it's a weak argument.

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body:
It isn't "too hard" to believe in Santa Klaus or fairies either, and children are able to grasp those things. And yet odds are you don't believe in them (I don't). Do we adults have a problem accepting those "basic truths" even children can grasp? For me, gods (including yours) are in the exact same bag.

I understand the concepts behind Yahweh/Allah, Kame and Kayru, Ymir, Izanagi and Inazami, etc.; I just don't think they explain anything. In fact once used for actual explanations, any of those hypotheses becomes way more complex than the theories and hypotheses I'm talking about.

Even the RNA world hypothesis relies on things we *know* to be there, like ribozymes; it doesn't rely on unattested entities (unnecessary complexity). The odds the hypothesis is correct are not 100% for me (remember, I don't "believe" in it in the same fashion as you believe in Christianity!), but are still greater than the odds of some unattested entity is outside the universe. 

Another thing you might have not realized is that *any* attribute given to some external god can be attributed to the universe instead, and the hypothesis will be *simpler*. (Even sentience, as pantheists play around with.)

Sorry to be blunt, but aren't you just trying to give a rational approach to something you believe for irrational reasons, such as faith?

>that sound mathematically impossible.

Remember the example with grains of rice? Do it once and it's impossible, do it a billion times and it's another story.

And "a billion" is a tiny number in this case. We're dealing with a molecular scale; a single drop of tap water has 6 800 000 billions of atoms of carbon (see note). What about the oceans?

There's absolutely no reason for me to believe in your god, or even consider it a viable explanation for the natural world.
___________________________

NOTE: some boring math stuff. Feel free to skip it if you want, it's just to back up the number.

Concentration of CO₂ in tap water is 10ppm. The mass of a drop of water is around 0.05g. The molar mass of carbon dioxide is 44.01g/mol, and there are 6.022\*10²³/mol in a mol.

(10g CO₂/10⁶g H₂O)\*(0.05g H₂O)/(44g CO₂/mol)\*(6.022\*10²³/mol) = 6.8\*10¹⁵ atoms of carbon. 

Worth noting that the concentration of carbon atoms in the oceans is likely *larger* than the concentration of carbon dioxide in tap water.

EDIT - some rewording, for succinctness.
body_html:
It isn't "too hard" to believe in Santa Klaus or fairies either, and children are able to grasp those things. And yet odds are you don't believe in them (I don't). Do we adults have a problem accepting those "basic truths" even children can grasp? For me, gods (including yours) are in the exact same bag.

Even the RNA world hypothesis relies on things we know to be there, like ribozymes; it doesn't rely on unattested entities (unnecessary complexity). The odds the hypothesis is correct are not 100% for me (remember, I don't "believe" in it in the same fashion as you believe in Christianity!), but are still greater than the odds of some unattested entity is outside the universe.

Another thing you might have not realized is that any attribute given to some external god can be attributed to the universe instead, and the hypothesis will be simpler. (Even sentience, as pantheists play around with.)

Sorry to be blunt, but aren't you just trying to give a rational approach to something you believe for irrational reasons, such as faith?

If you grew up in the Middle East, it's reasonable to assume you'd believe in Allah over the Christian god. You don't lay them all them out in front of you and objectively decide which to believe in.

parent.body:
>Regarding the oscillatory universe hypothesis, it couldn't be infinite, because how could infinite time have already progressed?

"Progress" would require a point of reference; a beginning. But under that hypothesis, there wouldn't be a beginning, we could at most say "in comparison with *now*, it *regresses* infinitely". 

>Also, you still have to question what formulated that structure - it's too complex to occur for no reason.

We don't need anyone "formulating" a chemical reaction, in order for it to happen. Given the right conditions it will eventually happen, for no other reason than "both molecules hit each other in a specific angle".

Lemme use an analogy. You're in the corner of a room, blindfolded, trying to throw a grain of rice inside a tiny glass in the opposite corner of the room. You'll likely fail, right? Right. But what if you tried again, with another grain of rice? And again? What if you had a billion grains of rice, and enough patience to keep trying? Then it's likely you'd be able to throw *at least* one grain inside that small glass.

In other words: yes, it is complex, but even complex events are bound to succeed if repeated enough times. Chemistry works *a lot* like this - on a molecular level even statistically unlikely reactions are happening all the time. 

And once that first self-replicating molecule pops up, from trivial reactions (no matter how unlikely they are!), it starts replicating like crazy, exponentially. And as there are more and more copies of that molecule, the odds some mutation makes it a better self-replicator *also* increase.

>And honestly it requires a lot more faith to believe that life comes from non-life, and the universe created itself, than to believe in an omnipotent God who created life and the universe.

But wouldn't a god - specially an omnipotent god, as the Jewish/Christian Yahweh - be *even more complex?*

It's also worth noting I don't really have "faith" on those two hypotheses. If they turn out wrong, for me, there's still no reason to believe in gods - again, doubt is my default.
parent.body_html:
Regarding the oscillatory universe hypothesis, it couldn't be infinite, because how could infinite time have already progressed?

"Progress" would require a point of reference; a beginning. But under that hypothesis, there wouldn't be a beginning, we could at most say "in comparison with now, it regresses infinitely".

Also, you still have to question what formulated that structure - it's too complex to occur for no reason.

We don't need anyone "formulating" a chemical reaction, in order for it to happen. Given the right conditions it will eventually happen, for no other reason than "both molecules hit each other in a specific angle".

Lemme use an analogy. You're in the corner of a room, blindfolded, trying to throw a grain of rice inside a tiny glass in the opposite corner of the room. You'll likely fail, right? Right. But what if you tried again, with another grain of rice? And again? What if you had a billion grains of rice, and enough patience to keep trying? Then it's likely you'd be able to throw at least one grain inside that small glass.

In other words: yes, it is complex, but even complex events are bound to succeed if repeated enough times. Chemistry works a lot like this - on a molecular level even statistically unlikely reactions are happening all the time.

And once that first self-replicating molecule pops up, from trivial reactions (no matter how unlikely they are!), it starts replicating like crazy, exponentially. And as there are more and more copies of that molecule, the odds some mutation makes it a better self-replicator also increase.

And honestly it requires a lot more faith to believe that life comes from non-life, and the universe created itself, than to believe in an omnipotent God who created life and the universe.

But wouldn't a god - specially an omnipotent god, as the Jewish/Christian Yahweh - be even more complex?

It's also worth noting I don't really have "faith" on those two hypotheses. If they turn out wrong, for me, there's still no reason to believe in gods - again, doubt is my default.

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body:
>molecules

If abiogenesis + RNA world are correct: molecules behind the proto-life would mostly come from simpler, energetically stable molecules already found in Earth, formed by common atoms.

(Those atoms come from nuclear fusion in stars; this is well-attested and already common knowledge.)

>matter

If the oscillatory universe hypothesis is correct: "what's the source of matter" is a moot point, matter=energy would be always in the universe, just changing states. (Note: the equivalence between matter and energy is shown by relativity.)

Note those explanations do add complexity due to the *events* they claim (e.g. "life started from RNA"). But they do **not** add complexity from the mechanics being claimed (e.g. "UV rays can force reactions into nucleic acids") - because those mechanics are already necessary to explain unrelated phenomena, such as the correlation between UV rays and skin cancer or compounds found after lightning strikes. 

Are there holes? Hell yeah, more than a sieve. But there's no reason to fill those holes with an unfalsifiable "God-of-the-gaps" that doesn't actually explain anything. 

>Existence

Existence of what? If matter or life: see above.
body_html:
molecules

If abiogenesis + RNA world are correct: molecules behind the proto-life would mostly come from simpler, energetically stable molecules already found in Earth, formed by common atoms.

(Those atoms come from nuclear fusion in stars; this is well-attested and already common knowledge.)

matter

If the oscillatory universe hypothesis is correct: "what's the source of matter" is a moot point, matter=energy would be always in the universe, just changing states. (Note: the equivalence between matter and energy is shown by relativity.)

Note those explanations do add complexity due to the events they claim (e.g. "life started from RNA"). But they do not add complexity from the mechanics being claimed (e.g. "UV rays can force reactions into nucleic acids") - because those mechanics are already necessary to explain unrelated phenomena, such as the correlation between UV rays and skin cancer or compounds found after lightning strikes.

Are there holes? Hell yeah, more than a sieve. But there's no reason to fill those holes with an unfalsifiable "God-of-the-gaps" that doesn't actually explain anything.

Existence

Existence of what? If matter or life: see above.

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body:
Some. But NONE of the ones I asked:

If there's an omnipotent god:

Why doesn't he do anything?

Why doesn't he reveal himself?

Why does he allow bad things to happen?

Why didn't he foresee all the bad things that were going to happen?

Why did he choose for all these bad things to happen? Cancer. Bone cancer. Bone cancer in children. If someone had the ability to fix that, and chose not to, then that's a pretty good argument that the person is not a good person. Not the sort you want to emulate. And certainly not the sort of person you want to take order or advice from.

Does he have the ability to limit his own abilities? Afterwards, is he still omnipotent?

Can he make a rock so heavy even he can't lift it?

If he's omnipotent and can see everything in the universe, why would he care about a speck of dust of one random galaxy?

If he hand-made this world, and hand-made humans, why are there so many flaws? Cancer, as mentioned. But old-age, grey hair, balding, wisdom teeth, the need for a constant supply of vitamin C. Other animals don't need that. Others also just deal with cancer better Whales don't get cancer. Their immune system is simply better at fighting it. (They have to be, otherwise they have so many cells that cancer would take over before they hit maturity). Why are people born predisposed to addiction? Why are people born with deformities? What part of god's plan is to mentally cripple children?

> before even allowing me to answer you

What the hell? I'm asking you, repeatedly, for some answers. That's not unreasonable as you've stated that the idea of an omnipotent god is quite simple. I'm giving you a lot of changes here. But you seem to be RUNNING AWAY.  All you told me is you don't have investments or loans.

parent.body:
Some. But NONE of the ones I asked:

If there's an omnipotent god:

Why doesn't he do anything?

Why doesn't he reveal himself?

Why does he allow bad things to happen?

Why didn't he foresee all the bad things that were going to happen?

Why did he choose for all these bad things to happen? Cancer. Bone cancer. Bone cancer in children. If someone had the ability to fix that, and chose not to, then that's a pretty good argument that the person is not a good person. Not the sort you want to emulate. And certainly not the sort of person you want to take order or advice from.

Does he have the ability to limit his own abilities? Afterwards, is he still omnipotent?

Can he make a rock so heavy even he can't lift it?

If he's omnipotent and can see everything in the universe, why would he care about a speck of dust of one random galaxy?

If he hand-made this world, and hand-made humans, why are there so many flaws? Cancer, as mentioned. But old-age, grey hair, balding, wisdom teeth, the need for a constant supply of vitamin C. Other animals don't need that. Others also just deal with cancer better Whales don't get cancer. Their immune system is simply better at fighting it. (They have to be, otherwise they have so many cells that cancer would take over before they hit maturity). Why are people born predisposed to addiction? Why are people born with deformities? What part of god's plan is to mentally cripple children?

> before even allowing me to answer you

What the hell? I'm asking you, repeatedly, for some answers. That's not unreasonable as you've stated that the idea of an omnipotent god is quite simple. I'm giving you a lot of changes here. But you seem to be RUNNING AWAY.  All you told me is you don't have investments or loans.

body:
Yeah... In college we've got similar problems with unlearning all the brainwashing kids pick up while at church. Replacing it with verifiable truth with a boatload of interlocking and cross supporting evidence. 

Speaking of which, 

>God does work intimately with humans on a personal and societal level every day. 

Got any evidence for that?

Anything?  Could I say that the ghost of Genghis Khan works intimately with everyone on a personal and societal level every day, but you just can't see it, or know how, or ask any details, and you simply need faith in Genghis? Or  aliens. Or Santa Clause. Or Obama. If I said Obama goes out, every day, and intimately helps everyone with their life and society on the whole, and while I couldn't provide any evidence, you just had to have faith..... how would you respond to that?

author.bio:
Come to: http://christianmusicreleases.com for the latest new Christian music.

Also check out: https://ruqqus.com/+ChristianMusic
author.bio_html:
Come to: http://christianmusicreleases.com for the latest new Christian music.

body:
Good question.

After mankind (which at the time consisted of just Adam and Eve) broke the one rule in the garden of Eden, the consequences were: the tainting of the world, difficulty in childbirth, complicated relations between men and women, and eventual death. Man was warned in advance. All they had to do was avoid the fruit of **one tree** in the garden, but instead, they listened to the devil in the form of a serpent, who tricked them into thinking they would become wise like God. 

They gained the knowledge of good and evil, and as they were no longer innocent, were guilty of their trespass of the rule.

So, with the fall of mankind came disease, meat eating (including some animals becoming meat eaters), natural disasters, and a limited lifespan. God does have the ability to fix cancer, and in some cases, he has healed people miraculously of cancer, where doctors have stated there is no scientific reason why they were healed, and it was attributed only to God.

But in general we have disease and death, and a lot of suffering in life. Does God want that? No? But in order for God to allow free will, he has to allow people to break the rules, and reap the consequences of their rule-breaking. 

This particular sin by Adam and Eve made the earth a hostile world. It would be worse though for God to not allow free will. And he brought Jesus as an escape route for man to avoid eternal death in hellfire, a place of punishment reserved initially only for fallen angels who once rebelled against God in heaven.

God doesn't want disease. He doesn't want death. And in heaven, there will be no disease and no death anymore. All children who die without the knowledge of right and wrong (at the age of innocence) will get a free pass to heaven. For those who do have that knowledge, he will give them ample opportunity to come into a relationship with Jesus in order for them to go to heaven when they die.

Oh, and in some cases, science can cure these cancers. God allows mankind to learn and control his environment and situation to a degree. So I think God is showing the maximum mercy that can be allowed while still allowing free will. God is a gentleman, and won't force you to follow him or to be his friend. But without him, the only future you have is in the eternal lake of fire.

HENCE: that's a pretty good argument that the person is not a good person.

>, he has healed people miraculously of cancer, where doctors have stated there is no scientific reason why they were healed, and it was attributed only to God.

Heeeeey, pulling out the ol' classic.  So god has no idea what people are going to do.  He's blind as a bat when it comes to psychology. author.bio:

body:
Just because God is omnipotent doesn't mean that he is required or somehow obligated to act in a way that you think is moral. Yes, God knows all the sins we will all commit, and our final destinations. Yet he still allows free will to occur because not doing so would make him a tyrant and we wouldn't truly be human without our free will. God made Lucifer, who was the greatest angel in heaven at one point, but Lucifer became a narcissist and thought he could overthrow God himself. He lost badly, and has been seeking vengeance ever since. God allows Satan the adversary to roam freely and tempt people because in order for us to have a fair choice, we must presented with both options: the opportunity to do good and to do evil.

God never forces us to make our eternal choice of heaven or hell. It is always decided by us.

There are many, many stories, books, videos, articles, that I could provide on the subject. Perhaps we should be very specific, because I can't go over all of them, it would take too much time.

God knows all. But he allows us the freedom to choose.

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body:
>Just because God is omnipotent doesn't mean that he is required or somehow obligated to act in a way that you think is moral.

...For me to consider him moral... yes he does.   That's pretty much the underpinning of free will existing. I get to decide what I think is moral or not.    And if this guy knew what adam and eve and the snake were going to do with the apple (which, if you believe he's omnipotent, HE DID) then I can absolutely blame him for putting the tree, the snake, eve, and adam there in the first place with the knowledge of their future actions.  He's blaming ignorant children for doing things he absolutely knew they were going to do.    Have you never raised children? You're responsible for them. Blaming them for being children is just downright VILE. The sort of abuse where CPS takes the children away.

>but Lucifer became a narcissist and thought he could overthrow God himself. 

But you JUST SAID god knows all our future sins.   An omnipotent God made Lucifer with the express intent of having Lucifer betray him. Is that really a betrayal or is it fulfilling his intended purpose? 

If he knows all, he knows what choices people are going to make and he's an absolute asshole.   OOOOORRRR He doesn't and he's an idiot when it comes to psychology.    Claiming both is a logical impossibility. You can't have both and have a consistent belief system. This is the basis of the Epicurus dilema I pointed out in my top level response. If you didn't pick up on it, or didn't know what it is, here it is again.

parent.body:
Just because God is omnipotent doesn't mean that he is required or somehow obligated to act in a way that you think is moral. Yes, God knows all the sins we will all commit, and our final destinations. Yet he still allows free will to occur because not doing so would make him a tyrant and we wouldn't truly be human without our free will. God made Lucifer, who was the greatest angel in heaven at one point, but Lucifer became a narcissist and thought he could overthrow God himself. He lost badly, and has been seeking vengeance ever since. God allows Satan the adversary to roam freely and tempt people because in order for us to have a fair choice, we must presented with both options: the opportunity to do good and to do evil.

God never forces us to make our eternal choice of heaven or hell. It is always decided by us.

There are many, many stories, books, videos, articles, that I could provide on the subject. Perhaps we should be very specific, because I can't go over all of them, it would take too much time.

God knows all. But he allows us the freedom to choose.

body:
So now you're reversing course on god allowing free will. Great.  If you and I are mere constructs, then why the hell am I getting blamed for how he made me?   If I'm not allowed to determine what is and isn't moral, then I don't really have any free will do I.

But regardless of free will existing and moral judgement,  if he's omnipotent he still set up adam, eve, the snake, and the tree knowing full well what was going to happen.   This is a logical inconsistency. You simply can't have it both ways.   

Let me boil it down to a simple question for you.   Did god know what adam, eve, and the snake were going to do with the apple?  Yes or no.

body:
I'm using my free will to judge him evil for knowingly making Eve and the snake damn humanity to disease and death and suffering.    

>But in general we have disease and death, and a lot of suffering in life. Does God want that? No? But in order for God to allow free will, he has to allow people to break the rules, and reap the consequences of their rule-breaking.

If he didn't want that, then why did he make Eve and the Snake? He knew what they were going to do and he then chose to make them.  SHOCK AND GASP! They did what he knew they were already going to do.   Why did he do that if he didn't' want that to happen?

...And it's not a contingency plan. Contingencies are for when things don't go according to plan. He KNOWS what's going to happen. It's not a contingency, it's Plan A. This is what he wanted all along because if he's omnipotent he knew all this was going to happen. EVEN with some sort of later plan to "fix it".... that's thousands of years of suffering for all humanity before Jesus comes about and get nailed for rabble rousing.   And then you have the gap in time between word of Jesus reaches India and China, where MOST OF HUMANITY lives. In the meantime, everyone is just burning and suffering eternal because they just weren't told yet.  Super.     

This is why omnipotency really complicates things.

body:
He made them because he chose to out of his good and perfect will. His will was to give people a choice. Of course he wants people to make the right choice, but it is not his job to make our choice for us.

There was a contingency though - man rebelled. That wasn't his choice, but it was his plan to be prepared for. I'm not claiming he didn't have knowledge. But he did prepare for it - and that was the contingency. Ideally, man would never sin, but in reality, man chooses to sin sometimes.

parent.body:
I'm using my free will to judge him evil for knowingly making Eve and the snake damn humanity to disease and death and suffering.    

>But in general we have disease and death, and a lot of suffering in life. Does God want that? No? But in order for God to allow free will, he has to allow people to break the rules, and reap the consequences of their rule-breaking.

If he didn't want that, then why did he make Eve and the Snake? He knew what they were going to do and he then chose to make them.  SHOCK AND GASP! They did what he knew they were already going to do.   Why did he do that if he didn't' want that to happen?

...And it's not a contingency plan. Contingencies are for when things don't go according to plan. He KNOWS what's going to happen. It's not a contingency, it's Plan A. This is what he wanted all along because if he's omnipotent he knew all this was going to happen. EVEN with some sort of later plan to "fix it".... that's thousands of years of suffering for all humanity before Jesus comes about and get nailed for rabble rousing.   And then you have the gap in time between word of Jesus reaches India and China, where MOST OF HUMANITY lives. In the meantime, everyone is just burning and suffering eternal because they just weren't told yet.  Super.     

This is why omnipotency really complicates things.
parent.body_html:
I'm using my free will to judge him evil for knowingly making Eve and the snake damn humanity to disease and death and suffering.

But in general we have disease and death, and a lot of suffering in life. Does God want that? No? But in order for God to allow free will, he has to allow people to break the rules, and reap the consequences of their rule-breaking.

If he didn't want that, then why did he make Eve and the Snake? He knew what they were going to do and he then chose to make them. SHOCK AND GASP! They did what he knew they were already going to do. Why did he do that if he didn't' want that to happen?

...And it's not a contingency plan. Contingencies are for when things don't go according to plan. He KNOWS what's going to happen. It's not a contingency, it's Plan A. This is what he wanted all along because if he's omnipotent he knew all this was going to happen. EVEN with some sort of later plan to "fix it".... that's thousands of years of suffering for all humanity before Jesus comes about and get nailed for rabble rousing. And then you have the gap in time between word of Jesus reaches India and China, where MOST OF HUMANITY lives. In the meantime, everyone is just burning and suffering eternal because they just weren't told yet. Super.

This is why omnipotency really complicates things.

body:
Enough hyperbole, noonemustknow, I've given you plenty of room to learn to be a reasonable debater here, and you've failed us once again. Your excessive use of Caps Lock doesn't give you a winning argument.

I haven't changed my story. God has an ideal will for everyone's life. Unfortunately, we are all prone to sin, not out of God's design, but of our own personal choice. That has nothing to do with God's creation, but it is our own decision.

So in ideal circumstances, we don't sin and choose the path that God has for us. In less ideal circumstances, we sin, but we repent, and so God rectifies the circumstances to some degree. In the worst case scenario, we sin and don't repent, and don't receive salvation, and the best life we receive is this life, and are subject to eternal damnation after death.

You've been exiled for being illogical, not listening, being rude, not following guidelines consistently, and not debating honestly.

body:
Lol, your philosophical approach to religion is a sad cope when you know you lack any actual evidence for God's existence.   I had to look up this lunacy, here's a delightful quote:  

"Reformed epistemology is a view in the epistemology of religious belief, which holds that the belief that there is a God can be properly basic.  Alvin Plantinga (1983) develops this view.  Plantinga holds that an individual may rationally believe that there is a God even though the individual does not possess sufficient evidence to convince an agnostic."

This is one of a staggering number of philosophies, and I love that you've latched onto one that let's you live in a fantasy world with no need to justify how it works.

I might be wrong with understanding your ridiculous means of dodging the burden of proof, but if you want to hide in philosophy to get away from it be my guest.

body:
God has never let me down. He's always there for me. When I die, I know my final destination. And I know I'm never alone.

God explains the mystery of creation through the Bible, and how he holds the whole world together, the souls of all creation, the tiny parts of our bodies etched with cruciform laminin. The only thing atheists and agnostics have is mathematical impossibility that everything is by chance, and a clear universal design with no clear designer.

body:
I think God placed limits on us so we could grow infinitely. We learn, develop ourselves, make achievements, but it's always a progression. Life would be very boring if we were omniscient and omnipotent after a while. :)

We are emotionally important to God, because he loves us, even if we are by scale less significant to him as an ant. And yet he cared so much to create a universe for us and to sacrifice his son to give us a chance to enjoy eternity with him in paradise. :D

We are on our own in a vast and uncaring expanse of space and we had better take very good care of our life-supporting planet for as long as we can, because we don't have the tech to move out yet.

If you want to come up with some kind of "god made us stewards of the earth" gimmick to jostle some self-agency regarding environmentalism then go for it, I'll let you be.

I absolutely have a basis for asserting this proven fact.

body:
You really aren't paying attention to what I'm saying at all, are you?  I gotta repeat everything from the past few posts because you can't follow along?

Empty space is relatively benign to Earth's ability to sustain life.  Not for a human adrift without a suit, but to our planet as it currently exists.  You just explained why relatively common radiation isn't a concern to Earth's ability to sustain life.

The planet killing elements that you listed are extremely rare when you consider how small a portion of the space within the universe they endanger.  That's why Earth has survived as long as it has, it's number just hasn't come up yet because the odds of your proposed catastrophes are so slim.

So that's why it's not as dangerous (to earth's ability to host life) as you are making it out to be.  Everything is just so far away from everything else.

post.title: Atheists/Agnostics of Ruqqus, what pushes you away from a belief in God?

body: every reason i've ever had to believe in god and the supernatural has been weak and held up by wishful thinking. i rejected all the rational arguments for god in my teens, i've always thought that god must be an empirical matter. for years i went around thinking that the reasonable positions to hold are atheistic agosticism when you've got no evidence for god or theism with evidence. but the forms of evidence that i used to defend my belief with were weak, just a feeling that there's a god (religious experience) together with a feeling of absolute certainty beyond ordinary certainty. that's the trick right there, because of that feeling of certainty you're certain in your belief and you don't always think to question that part

Because people are raised around it. Of course they're going to believe in it when their parents, friends, and family all believe in it.

If you grew up in the Middle East, it's reasonable to assume you'd believe in Allah over the Christian god. You don't lay them all them out in front of you and objectively decide which to believe in.
